awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Uplift or climate change? Determining the primary driver of deep canyon incision in the eastern cordillera, southern Peru
awd_abstract_narration:
Competition between the growth of new topography by tectonic uplift and erosion that wears it down occurs in many mountain regions. Earth scientists recognize that the ability of rivers to erode depends on how much water is delivered to the mountains, and that changes between wetter or dryer climates should influence topography.  The expectation is that changes in climate and the resulting change in erosion are reflected in the topography of a landscape. This project focuses on the Eastern Cordillera of southern Peru, where deep canyons carved into the Central Andean Plateau margin reflect either tectonic uplift or an increase in erosional efficiency due to climate change. The research incorporates newly-developed methods for diagnosing the effects of climate on topography as part of a field-based investigation to determine the degree to which climate-driven changes in erosional efficiency are responsible for canyon cutting. New remote analysis methods are used to differentiate signatures of tectonic uplift driven erosion and climate driven erosion in topography. Improving the fidelity of these remote methods has considerable societal value because they are an inexpensive and efficient means of hazard assessment in areas where the presence or absence of tectonic uplift, and the resulting effect on seismicity, are uncertain. Additionally, this project wll benefit society by: 1) essential STEM training of three US graduate students including two women, as well as several Peruvian undergraduates; 2) international collaborations with both Peruvian and German universities; and 3) improved STEM education development in Peru and US at the undergraduate, graduate, and professional levels.

Determination of an active tectonic driver of mountain uplift and the geometry of related structures is critical to resolving how strongly climate and tectonics are coupled. This project tests competing hypotheses for the proximal drivers of canyon cutting into the Eastern Cordillera: incision driven by active rock uplift vs. incision into a previously uplifted plateau margin triggered by climate change. Integration of observations and analyses of the deformation history, landscape morphology, precipitation patterns, and spatial and temporal patterns of erosion and exhumation is used to definitively and quantitatively evaluate the relative importance of active rock uplift and climate change in landscape evolution. Analyses focus on: 1. estimating millennial-scale erosion rates from cosmogenic 10Be concentrations in modern river sands, 2. assessing the role of rainfall in the relation between topography and erosion rate, 3. analyzing cooling ages of low-temperature thermochronometers (AHe, AFT, ZHe) provided by a complementary study, 4. refining geologic mapping and developing balanced cross sections, and 5. integrating all data in models to quantitatively test hypotheses. Results will have broad implications for: 1. the general applicability and fidelity of proposed methods for diagnosing the primary causes of canyon cutting based on analysis of geomorphic data, 2. further development of a methodology to quantitatively link geometry, displacement and rates on faults to exhumation rates, erosion rate patterns and the resulting landscape morphology, 3. quantitative, observation-based understanding of the sensitivity of erosion rates to annual rainfall, and 4. understanding of the nature and strength of linkages among climate, topography, erosion, and tectonics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project were: (1) to quantify the spatial pattern of erosion rates along four canyons situated along the strike of, and incised into, the Eastern Andean Escarpment in southern Peru and explore relationships to remotely sensed topographic and rainfall datasets; (2) to evaluate the capacity of stream-power based incision models to isolate diagnostic patterns of climate- or uplift-driven incision in a landscape characterized by a dramatic orographic rainfall gradient; (3) to use these results to assess the relative importance and/or necessity of tectonic uplift and climate change as drivers of canyon cutting in southern Peru; (4) to further domestic and international collaborations between universities in US, Peru, and Germany; and (5) to train and build international collaborative networks for graduate and undergraduate students. Goals (1-3) are intellectual merit goals, and (4-5) are broader impact goals.

The project has been successful, and these goals have largely been met, though debate and unanswered questions remain: Goals (1), (2), (4), and (5) have been fully satisfied with outcomes reflected in ASU-generated research products (1 Ph.D. dissertation and 3 published journal articles) and in research products generated by formal and informal collaborators at University of Pittsburgh and the University of Tuebingen Germany, respectively. Goals (4) and (5) were met through mentoring activities, scientific training, taking on the role of lead author on papers, presenting research results at national and international meetings, and sustained interactions – mostly by zoom – with collaborators in Peru, Pennsylvania, and Germany, with presentations and discussions lead by the PhD students funded on this project.

We produced and published 25 new catchment-mean erosion rates in southern Peru and re-analyzed 43 previously published catchment-mean erosion rates in northern Bolivia (Leonard et al., 2023; 2024). These data establish the spatial pattern of erosion rates across the Eastern Andean Escarpment and our analysis shows how topography and rainfall combine to influence erosion rates. This allows us to effectively interpolate and extrapolate our data to regional scales. We also demonstrate the general utility of the discharge-based channel steepness as a proxy for erosion and rock uplift rates in the presence of a strong orographic rainfall gradient. However, despite progress, uncertainty remains on the relative contributions of climatic and tectonic drivers of canyon incision in southern Peru. Collectively with our collaborators we have clearly established that the topography and distribution of low-temperature cooling ages cannot be attributed to solely climate-driven canyon incision since the early Pliocene – tectonic rock uplift has been sustained through this period and is required to explain available data. However, whereas our work at ASU suggests that recent plateau uplift is the primary driver of young canyon incision, our formal collaborators at U. Pittsburgh concur that a young phase of canyon cutting is required to explain available data but remain agnostic to the cause. Our informal collaborators at U. Tuebingen, on the other hand, favor a significant role of climate change. Despite this remaining debate, our analysis demonstrates that the patterns and rates of longer-term exhumation rates from low-temperature thermochronology are consistent with both the patterns and rates of millennial-scale erosion rates determined from cosmogenic isotope concentrations in river sands and the patterns of unit stream power inferred from topography and the spatial distribution of rainfall. In addition, sampled river catchments appear to be in equilibrium; the topography of each appears to be adjusted to the modern climate and active uplift. Together these observations suggest canyon incision was dominantly driven by rock uplift since the early Pliocene. Our data show that a Pliocene climate change is not required to satisfy all available data and thus that the formation of deeply incised canyons along the eastern flank of the Andes in southern Peru reflect recent plateau uplift.
